Title: ShakeAlertLA to be replaced by statewide earthquake early-warning app
Body: Share  LOS ANGELES - The city's ShakeAlertLA app will stop issuingÂ earthquake warnings after Dec. 31, and Mayor Eric Garcetti urged residentsÂ to download the statewide MyShake app that was built with the sameÂ technology and provides the same alerts. ShakeAlertLA was designed to notify residents when earthquakes with aÂ magnitude of 4.5 or higher occur.  "Los Angeles leads the nation in earthquake resilience, andÂ ShakeAlertLA showed how we can harness technology to provide critical warningÂ before an earthquake hits,'' Garcetti said in a statement. "The next `big one'Â is not a matter of if, but when, and we can all do our part to stay prepared,Â resilient and a few seconds ahead of the game by downloading the MyShake appÂ now.'' Gov. Gavin Newsom announced MyShake on Oct. 17, 2019, and since its release it has been downloaded more than 1 million times, according to theÂ mayor's office. "Through working cooperatively with the U.S. Geological Survey, theÂ city of Los Angeles delivered the country's first cell phone app for massÂ delivery of earthquake early warning alerts," U.S. Geological Survey DirectorÂ Jim Reilly said. "What we learned from our important pilot partnership withÂ the city of L.A. has benefited people throughout the West Coast as we expandÂ ShakeAlert.'' The MyShake system works the same way as ShakeAlertLA and detects earthquakes through ground-motion censors. If an earthquake with a significantmagnitude is detected, an alert message is issued, warning the public severalÂ seconds before shaking begins. ShakeAlertLA issued 100,000 early warning alerts of all recordableÂ earthquake activity since its launch in 2018, according to the mayor's office.  "On behalf of the governor and state of California, we thank MayorÂ Garcetti for his leadership and work to advance seismic safety,'' said MarkÂ Ghilarducci, director of the California Governor's Office of EmergencyÂ Services. "We are better positioned today because of the mayor's efforts andÂ encourage all Angelenos to access the statewide earthquake early warningÂ system, which can provide life-saving seconds to drop, cover and hold on beforeÂ an earthquake. We are pleased to be able to expand this life-saving technologyÂ to all Californians.'' ShakeAlertLA was meant to "serve as a bridge'' to a statewideÂ earthquake early warning system, according to the mayor's office, and cityÂ officials worked with other governments to assist them in developing earthquakeÂ early warning programs. Now that a statewide system is in place, the ShakeAlertLA app willÂ stop sending alerts at the start of 2021. The MyShake app is available for download through the Apple Store orÂ Google Play. "Through working cooperatively with the U.S. Geological Survey, theÂ city of Los Angeles delivered the country's first cell phone app for massÂ delivery of earthquake early warning alerts," U.S. Geological Survey DirectorÂ Jim Reilly said.
ShakeAlertLA issued 100,000 early warning alerts of all recordableÂ earthquake activity since its launch in 2018, according to the mayor's office.
We are pleased to be able to expand this life-saving technologyÂ to all Californians.'' Title: USGS: 2.7 magnitude earthquake reported near in southwest Virginia early Monday
Body: WFXRtv Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term.       RICHLANDS, Va. (WJHL/WFXR) â€” A 2.7 magnitude earthquake was reported early Monday morning in southwest Virginia. According to the United States Geological Survey (USGS), the earthquake was recorded 6.21 miles northwest of Richlands, which is in Tazewell County. The earthquake had a recorded depth of 11.37 miles, according to USGS.  The USGS Interactive Map places the earthquake just over the Tazewell/Buchanan County line in Buchanan County. Title: Magnitude 3.6 earthquake felt across Massachusetts Sunday morning
Body: A magnitude 3.6 earthquake was felt across Massachusetts Sunday morning, according to information from the United States Geological Survey and the flurry of social media posts online.  The USGS first reported it was a magnitude 4.2 earthquake then later classified it as a magnitude 3.6 earthquake.  People all across Massachusetts reported feeling the shaking from Cape Cod to Springfield. The Massachusetts National Weather tweeted out information about earthquake reported by the USGS.  The hashtags #MassEarthquake and #massquake began popping up on Twitter immediately after people felt the ground shake. â€œOh, so thatâ€™s what an earthquake feels like,â€ one person wrote on Twitter.  Thinking of my family back in Massachusetts this morning who almost spilled their morning Dunks in the great shakeup of Nov. 8#MassEarthquake Wow, that was different #MassEarthquake Still feels like a big truck coming up the driveway in a cartoon #MassQuake I knew I wasnâ€™t crazy!! About 10 minutes after nine this morning I felt my house beginning to shake under my feet, I live in Monson Massachusetts. I was thinking, maybe it was the train going bye, but the train never shook my house like that!! earthquake with a magnitude of 4.0 Just felt a small earthquake in Chatham, MA and Iâ€™m seeing lots of others from eastern MA report the same. Just waiting for the (justified) snark from the Left Coast to fire up now! #earthquake #snark Weird question. But was there just an earthquake in Springfield, Massachusetts? A magnitude 3.6 earthquake was felt across Massachusetts Sunday morning, according to information from the United States Geological Survey and the flurry of social media posts online.
The Massachusetts National Weather tweeted out information about earthquake reported by the USGS.
But was there just an earthquake in Springfield, Massachusetts?

Title: 4.0 magnitude earthquake reported near Stanley
Body: USGS reports the epicenter of the earthquake was 27 kilometers, approximately 16.7 miles northwest of Stanley. The last earthquake to hit near Stanley occurred on Oct. 12. Â That earthquake measured at a magnitude of 3.1, according to the USGS. Officials say the epicenter was 73 miles northeast of Boise along Idaho 21 near Elk Mountain. Several other earthquakes have been recorded in that area this year, with the largest, a 6.5-magnitude, hitting March 31. The shocks from that earthquake were strong enough to be felt around the region.Â  KTVB has not received any reports of damage connected to the Sunday earthquake. Title: 7.0 earthquake topples buildings in Turkey
Body: A strong earthquake in the Aegean Sea has shaken Turkey and Greece. Several buildings were wrecked in Turkeyâ€™s western Izmir province, according to officials, but there was no immediate information on casualties. ISTANBUL â€” A strong earthquake struck Friday between the Turkish coast and the Greek island of Samos, collapsing several buildings in Turkeyâ€™s western Izmir province and leaving at least four people dead. Dozens more were injured, while some damage to buildings and the road network, and four light injuries were also reported on Samos. Turkeyâ€™s Health Minister Fahrettin Koca tweeted that four people were killed in Izmir and 120 were injured. He said 38 ambulances, two ambulance helicopters and 35 medical rescue teams were working in Izmir. The European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre said the quake had a preliminary magnitude of 6.9 with an epicenter 13 kilometers (8 miles) north northeast of the Greek island of Samos. The United States Geological Survey put the magnitude at 7.0. It is common for preliminary magnitudes to differ in the early hours and days after a quake. Multiple aftershocks struck the region. Another footage from moment of #earthquake in #izmir #Turkey ,#deprem pic.twitter.com/jfEVkFDW3M â€” Global News (@GlbBreakNews) October 30, 2020   The European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre said the quake had a preliminary magnitude of 6.9, with an epicenter 13 kilometers (8 miles) north northeast of the Greek island of Samos. The United States Geological Survey put the magnitude at 7.0.  â€” Auskar Surbakti (@AuskarSurbakti) October 30, 2020   Turkish media showed wreckage of a multiple-story building in central Izmir, with people climbing it to start rescue efforts. Turkish media showed at least one woman being helped from the rubble of a collapsed building. Smoke was filmed in several spots in central Izmir. 20 buildings collapsed Izmir mayor Tunc Soyer told CNN Turk that about 20 buildings collapsed. The city is the third biggest in Turkey with about 4,5 million residents. Turkeyâ€™s interior minister tweeted six buildings in Izmir were destroyed. He said there were small cracks in some buildings in six other provinces. Izmirâ€™s governor said there was no immediate information on casualties. Turkish media said the earthquake was felt across the regions of Aegean and Marmara, including Istanbul. Istanbulâ€™s governor said there were no reports of damage in the city. A moment during #earthquake in #izmir #Turkey #depremizmir #Deprem #tsunami   â€” Global News (@GlbBreakNews) October 30, 2020   The quake was felt across the eastern Greek islands and even in the Greek capital Athens. Greek media said the residents of Samos and other islands fled their homes, while some rockfalls were reported. There were no immediate reports of injuries. Turkey and Greece reported aftershocks. The quake was also felt in Bulgaria. Greek seismologist Efthymios Lekkas told Greek state television ERT that it was still too early to say whether this was the main earthquake, although he said it was likely it was. â€œIt is an event that is evolving,â€ Lekkas said, adding that some damage had been reported in parts of Samos. A tsunami warning was issued, with residents of the Samos area told to stay away from the coastline. Water rose above the dock in the main harbor of Samos and flooded the street. The regional governor of the Samos region, Yiannis Stamoulis, said no injuries had been reported on the island. Residents have also been told to stay away from buildings, as aftershocks continued to rattle the area. Prosecutors plan to drop an involuntary manslaughter charge against Alec Baldwin in the fatal 2021 shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the Western film â€ Rust.â€ SpaceXâ€™s giant new rocket blasted off on its first test flight Thursday but exploded minutes after rising from the launch pad and crashed into the Gulf of Mexico. â€œThe truth matters. Lies have consequences,â€ said Dominion lawyer Justin Nelson in a news conference outside the courthouse after the announcement. Gunfire that erupted on busy highway in Maine is linked to a second crime scene where four people were found dead in a home. Oklahomaâ€™s governor is calling for the resignations of the four officials, one of whom also apparently made racist remarks in an audio recording. No people or satellites were aboard for this attempt. There wonâ€™t be another try until at least Wednesday. About 150 people walked at a Summerlin park on Sunday to raise awareness about antisemitism and to preserve the memory of the Holocaust.  In California and across the deserts of Arizona, there are flashes of color popping up after an unusually wet winter helped produce a so-called â€œSuperbloom.â€ A Massachusetts Air National Guard member was taken into custody Thursday in connection with the disclosure of highly classified military documents. Copyright Â© 2019 Las Vegas Review-Journal, Inc. | Privacy Policy | Terms of Service Powered by WordPress.com VIP
summ:
Several buildings were wrecked in Turkeyâ€™s western Izmir province, according to officials, but there was no immediate information on casualties.
ISTANBUL â€” A strong earthquake struck Friday between the Turkish coast and the Greek island of Samos, collapsing several buildings in Turkeyâ€™s western Izmir province and leaving at least four people dead.
The European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre said the quake had a preliminary magnitude of 6.9 with an epicenter 13 kilometers (8 miles) north northeast of the Greek island of Samos.

A moment during #earthquake in #izmir #Turkey #depremizmir #Deprem #tsunami   â€” Global News (@GlbBreakNews) October 30, 2020   The quake was felt across the eastern Greek islands and even in the Greek capital Athens.
Greek media said the residents of Samos and other islands fled their homes, while some rockfalls were reported.
The regional governor of the Samos region, Yiannis Stamoulis, said no injuries had been reported on the island.

Title: WATCH: Video shows workers' reaction as earthquake hits Alabama-Florida state line
Body: WKBN.com Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term.    A 3.8-magnitude earthquake hit near the Alabama-Florida state line Thursday morning    JAY, Fla. (WKRG) â€“ A passing truck? Thunder? Someone upstairs? Those were some initial thoughts when a 3.8-magnitude earthquake hit near the Alabama-Florida state line Thursday morning.  â€œStanding and just chatting with my coworkers and all of a sudden, there was a quick vibration, and then I looked around and it happened again within a few seconds,â€ Kamal Hossain said. The earthquake didnâ€™t bring catastrophe so he was happy to jest, telling his coworker, â€œItâ€™s probably that big guy walking around.â€ Down the street at Opieâ€™s Cafe and Coffee Shop, the quake rattled the sign above the cash register. â€œAll of a sudden, we feel something shaking and first we think itâ€™s my girls upstairs because theyâ€™re bringing in delivery,â€ said owner Laurie Elder. â€œThe next thing I know, I can feel it under my feet.â€ Copyright 2023 Nexstar Media Inc. Title: Google announces earthquake alert system for California Android devices
Body: Share KTVU - Google announced TuesdayÂ that it will sendÂ earthquake alerts to Android devices in California with a new technology.Â  Android phones will serve as a "mini seismometer" to detect when an earthquake might be happening, and will display information about the quake when the user searches on Google. The company said that its phones contain "tiny accelerometers that can sense signals that indicate an earthquake might be happening." If a phone detects a movement consistent with an earthquake, it will send the information to a server alongside the location. The server connects and checks against many phones to see if an earthquake is indeed happening.Â  Bay Area politicians, scientists and BART officials hopped on a train to experience first hand how the earthquake early warning system, called ShakeAlert, would work if a quake were to strike. There were no sudden stops. "To start, weâ€™ll use this technology to share a fast, accurate view of the impacted area on Google Search,"Â a press release stated.Â "When you look up 'earthquake'Â or 'earthquake near me,' youâ€™ll find relevant results for your area, along with helpful resources on what to do after an earthquake." Google said that they worked withÂ seismology and disaster experts to create a "crowdsourced" approach for detecting earthquakes.Â  "An early warning can help people prepare for shaking, but the public infrastructure to detect and alert everyone about an earthquake is costly to build and deploy," the release stated. summ:
Android phones will serve as a "mini seismometer" to detect when an earthquake might be happening, and will display information about the quake when the user searches on Google.
The company said that its phones contain "tiny accelerometers that can sense signals that indicate an earthquake might be happening." If a phone detects a movement consistent with an earthquake, it will send the information to a server alongside the location.

Title: Earthquake: 3.1 quake near Brawley, Calif.
Body: A swarm of mostly small earthquakes on Monday struck the Salton Sea area, one of the most seismically active areas of California.  More than a dozen temblors followed, one measuring 4.0 and several in the 3 range. Quake swarms are fairly common in this region, with some producing more than 1,000 small temblors. Scientists are carefully monitoring the series of quakes, as they are centered at the southern tip of the dangerous San Andreas fault. There is concern the swarm could trigger a larger event, a phenomenon that has occurred in that region in the past. Neil Driscoll, a geophysicist at UC San Diegoâ€™s Scripps Institution of Oceanography, pointed to a chain reaction that occurred in November 1987 when a 6.2 quake on the Elmore Ranch fault near the Salton Sea triggered a 6.6 temblor just over 11 hours later on the Superstition Hills fault. Both quakes were widely felt in San Diego County. â€œWe have had many swarms in that area over the years, and there has been no triggering of a fault, but weâ€™re watching this closely,â€ said Driscoll. â€œWe canâ€™t say whether it is or isnâ€™t going to trigger a larger earthquake.â€ Did you feel these earthquake? Consider reporting what you felt to the USGS. Even if you didn't feel this small earthquake, you never know when the Big One is going to strike. Ready yourself by following our five-step earthquake preparedness guide and building your own emergency kit. This story was automatically generated by Quakebot, a computer application that monitors the latest earthquakes detected by the USGS. A Times editor reviewed the post before it was published. If you're interested in learning more about the system, visit our list of frequently asked questions. San Diego Union-Tribune staff writer Gary Robbins contributed to this report. Title: People rattled after earthquake felt in North Carolina causes significant damage
Body: WNCT Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term.       SPARTA, N.C. (WGHP) â€” People in North Carolina are still shaken after Sunday morningâ€™s 5.1 magnitude earthquake.  In Sparta, North Carolina, it left a significant amount of damage downtown, with bricks falling off several buildings. â€œWe had gotten woken up by a boom a little after two and couldnâ€™t go back to sleep,â€ said Jacob Church, a Sparta resident. â€œAt first it was like, â€˜Whatâ€™s going on?â€™ None of us were injured. I think itâ€™s a cool thing to be a part of that,â€ said Brandon Lineberry, who was visiting at the time. The quake rattled a cemetery so hard, it uprooted headstones from the ground. Just a few miles from downtown, the North Carolina Department of Transportation was dealing with the damage to a water main. â€œWeâ€™re just trying to get it back open. Itâ€™s buckled up the road a little from the water main, from the earthquake, and weâ€™re just trying to get it back to normal,â€ said Jeffery Jones, with the North Carolina Department of Transportation. The damage was significant at Scottâ€™s Landscaping Nursery and Farms, leaving several cracks in the parking lot and shattering pottery. â€œItâ€™s been a rough morning. You donâ€™t expect anything like this to happen here because it doesnâ€™t happen here,â€ said owner Scott Smith, adding that â€œ2020 has been a rough year for a lot of people.â€ The mayor of Sparta, Wes Brinegar, issued a state of emergency Sunday after the earthquake hit. No injuries had been reported.Â  The mayor said Sunday there was widespread minor damage to homes, with structures and chimneys being knocked off.Â  Copyright 2023 Nexstar Media Inc. Title: Did your pet seem to 'know' the earthquake was coming?
Body: (WBTV) - Did your pet act strangely before the Earth started shaking during this morningâ€™s earthquake? Stefanie Scism asked WBTV anchor Maureen Oâ€™Boyle in an email, â€œDid anyone else report their dogs acting crazy this morning BEFORE the shaking?â€ For centuries, people have shared observations just like Scismâ€™s, according to the United States Geological Survey, with people recalling the moments before an earthquake when animals exhibited bizarre behavior. This is what Scism says happened to her Sunday morning. â€œI have 3 dogs and the only reason I was up is they were trying to climb on me,â€ she said. â€œThey NEVER do that.â€ Weâ€™ll get to what seismologists say about this in a moment. But it turns out Scismâ€™s experience this morning was not unique. Soon after the earthquake, WBTV First Alert Meteorologist Leigh Brock was on Facebook Live explaining to viewers what they had just experienced. It was a 5.1 magnitude earthquake, the epicenter in Sparta, North Carolina. As Brock was sharing her knowledge, viewers started sharing their experiences. Some talked specifically about their pets. â€œThere wasnâ€™t a lot of talk at that point of damage,â€ Brock said. â€œBut a lot of viewers were saying their dogs were barking and running around and acting strange." After experiencing something similar in California in the mid-90â€²s during an earthquake, Oâ€™Boyle wanted to believe her dog â€œknewâ€ the earthquake was coming. Oâ€™Boyle remembers it like it was yesterday. She was living in a home in the hills above West Hollywood. Her three-year-old mutt Sammy started arching his back and lifting his paws like the ground was suddenly hot. That was immediately followed by deep howling sound. It was bizarre, to say the least. Then, boom. Oâ€™Boyleâ€™s house didnâ€™t shake. She described it more as a giant â€œthud,â€ as if the house was a boat making a sudden bump into the dock. Oâ€™Boyle wanted to believe her dog was trying to â€œwarnâ€ her of what was coming. But our pets will never cause seismologists to lose their jobs.  â€œWe can easily explain the cause of unusual animal behavior seconds before humans feel an earthquake,â€ according to an article on the USGS web site. â€œVery few humans notice the smaller P wave that travels the fastest from the earthquake source and arrives before the larger S wave. But many animals with more keen senses are able to feel the P wave seconds before the S wave arrives. As for sensing an impending earthquake days or weeks before it occurs, thatâ€™s a different story,â€ the article explains,â€ the article continued. So yes, there is something to it. That â€œP waveâ€ may be why your dog, like all three of Scismâ€™s did things they never do moments before the Earth started to move. It would be wonderful if animals could â€œwarnâ€ us when an earthquake is coming, but we would need more than seconds. The USGS writes, â€œHowever, consistent and reliable behavior prior to seismic events, and a mechanism explaining how it could work, still eludes us.â€ Copyright 2020 WBTV. All rights reserved.
summ:
(WBTV) - Did your pet act strangely before the Earth started shaking during this morningâ€™s earthquake?
Stefanie Scism asked WBTV anchor Maureen Oâ€™Boyle in an email, â€œDid anyone else report their dogs acting crazy this morning BEFORE the shaking?â€ For centuries, people have shared observations just like Scismâ€™s, according to the United States Geological Survey, with people recalling the moments before an earthquake when animals exhibited bizarre behavior.
Soon after the earthquake, WBTV First Alert Meteorologist Leigh Brock was on Facebook Live explaining to viewers what they had just experienced.
â€œBut a lot of viewers were saying their dogs were barking and running around and acting strange." After experiencing something similar in California in the mid-90â€²s during an earthquake, Oâ€™Boyle wanted to believe her dog â€œknewâ€ the earthquake was coming.
â€œWe can easily explain the cause of unusual animal behavior seconds before humans feel an earthquake,â€ according to an article on the USGS web site.
As for sensing an impending earthquake days or weeks before it occurs, thatâ€™s a different story,â€ the article explains,â€ the article continued.

Title: Residents Rocked, House Walls Buckle as Powerful Earthquake Rocks North Carolina
Body: A 5.1 magnitude earthquake rocked North Carolina Sunday after a chain of smaller quakes had jolted parts of the state late Saturday and early Sunday.  â€œThe information center received more than 6,000 reports of the earthquake in a 200-mile radius that touches seven states,â€ he said. The quake was the strongest to hit North Carolina since a 1916 earthquake that registered 5.2 on the scale, the News & Observer reported. Immediate reports of damage included cracks in pavement, facades on homes losing bricks or stones, or items falling from store shelves. No immediate reports of injuries were received. â€You knew right away it was an earthquake. There was no question about it,â€ said Shari Carricker, according to the Charlotte Observer. â€œWe have no damage, except the coffee in my husbandâ€™s coffee cup sloshed out,â€ she said. â€œBut it was scary. Really, really scary,â€ she said. Many tweeted about the impacts or shared photos of damage. Damage to a home in Sparta NC. 5.1 earthquake. Local report says epi center was at Pine Swamp and hwy 21. Not official that Im aware of yet. pic.twitter.com/nLJQPtCz1z â€” Cello Mom (@Cello_mama) August 9, 2020  Food Lion in Sparta NC pic.twitter.com/0dlDoEziPy â€” Cello Mom (@Cello_mama) August 9, 2020   ? Tom Willis pic.twitter.com/0XhJ8xHtjc â€” WMBF News (@wmbfnews) August 9, 2020  Callie Carson was cooking in a 27-foot camper when everything started to shake. â€œIt was kind of unnerving,â€ she told the News & Observer. â€œMy husband and I looked at each other and said, â€˜Was that an earthquake?â€™â€ â€œThere is no way there was an earthquake up here. Thatâ€™s just not logical,â€ she said. â€œ2020 has defied all innate logic, so why not an earthquake? Why not?â€ Baldwin said the Appalachian mountains are old, but that does not mean they are never active. â€œThey are old mountains,â€ Baldwin told the News & Observer. â€œThey were formed a long time ago by faulting. And these faults â€¦ they get reactivated every now and again. The stresses build up and reactivate some of these old faults.â€ We are committed to truth and accuracy in all of our journalism.  Read our editorial standards. Get the latest news delivered right to your email. News, Politics, Culture, and more in realtime.
summ:
â€œThe information center received more than 6,000 reports of the earthquake in a 200-mile radius that touches seven states,â€ he said.
The quake was the strongest to hit North Carolina since a 1916 earthquake that registered 5.2 on the scale, the News & Observer reported.
â€œWe have no damage, except the coffee in my husbandâ€™s coffee cup sloshed out,â€ she said.
Really, really scary,â€ she said.
â€œThey are old mountains,â€ Baldwin told the News & Observer.

Title: 5.1 magnitude earthquake rattles Virginia, North Carolina
Body: Menu RICHMOND, Va. -- A 5.1 magnitude earthquake rattled parts of Virginia and North Carolina Sunday morning. There have been no immediate reports of damage, nor injuries.  Sunday's earthquake is one of the biggest to impact Virginia since the 5.8-magnitude earthquake centered in Mineral, Virginia on August 23, 2011. And the largest earthquake in North Carolina since a 5.2 earthquake in 1916. "According to the U.S. Geological Survey database, the 5.1 magnitude earthquake near Sparta this morning is the second strongest earthquake to occur in North Carolina 1900," the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg Office wrote on Twitter. "The strongest was a 5.2 magnitude earthquake near Skyland, North Carolina in February 1916." The 5.1 magnitude earthquake was preceded by multiple, smaller "foreshocks" on Saturday. Multiple aftershocks are expected over the next few weeks. The USGS forecasted a 4 percent chance of one or more aftershocks that are larger than magnitude 5.1. This story originally reported by Mike Stone on wtvr.com. Report a typo
summ:
-- A 5.1 magnitude earthquake rattled parts of Virginia and North Carolina Sunday morning.
"The strongest was a 5.2 magnitude earthquake near Skyland, North Carolina in February 1916." The 5.1 magnitude earthquake was preceded by multiple, smaller "foreshocks" on Saturday.

Title: In 1981, scientists predicted an earthquake like the one that rattled the Alaska Peninsula this week
Body: Late Tuesday, state seismologist Michael West heard a text alarm. His phone informed him of a large earthquake beneath the ocean, just south of the Alaska Peninsula, about 60 miles southeast of the village of Sand Point. His first thought was that this â€” the biggest earthquake on the planet so far in 2020 â€” would cause a devastating tsunami. His second thought was that a longstanding earthquake mystery may have just been solved.  West and his colleagues at the University of Alaska Fairbanks Geophysical Institute were still awash in data one day after the event. But he was quick to point out a scientific paper written by the first Alaska state seismologist, John Davies, in 1981. All the large recent earthquakes on the Aleutian Subduction Zone, including the magnitude 7.8 in the â€œShumagin Gapâ€ that occurred July 21, 2020. (Graphic courtesy Alaska Earthquake Center)  In it, Davies and his co-workers proposed a â€œseismic gapâ€ just south of Sand Point. There, they wrote, was a swath of one of the worldâ€™s great subduction zones that had not ruptured in a long time. It was perhaps due. Davies made his prediction after field campaigns in the 1970s, during which he and his co-workers had installed seismometers near Popof Island, upon which the village of Sand Point (population 1,140) sits. â€œFrom 1938 to 1965, almost the entirety of the Alaska subduction zone ruptured,â€ West said. â€œThere were only two places that didnâ€™t rip â€” one in the Yakutat area and another in the Shumagin Islands (where the July 21 earthquake occurred). â€œHere, you have this 1981 paper that says youâ€™ve ruptured everything except these sections, and thatâ€™s where you should expect the next big earthquake.â€ [Alaska quake that prompted tsunami evacuations, but no big wave, may offer clue in scientific debate]  â€œThe Pacific Plate is careening northwestward a couple of inches each year into the stronger North American Plate,â€ he said. â€œThis forces the Pacific Plate to thrust down under Alaska. Major earthquakes happen at the boundary where these two plates rub together.â€ John Davies, who wrote the paper predicting an earthquake like the one that happened Tuesday night, was elected to the Alaska State Legislature in 1993. He then had to resign from his position at the Geophysical Institute, where, like West, he was the state seismologist. Daviesâ€™ doctorate work, executed in Skwentna, Alaska, helped prove the newish theory of plate tectonics, in which scientists like his mentor David Stone had argued that Earthâ€™s crust is composed of colossal blocks shoving into one another. Davies showed that the Pacific Plate was indeed diving deep beneath Anchorage, and reached almost to Denali. After turning to politics, Davis never went back to seismology. The day after the 2020 earthquake, he and his wife, Linda Schandelmeier, were making kimchi from Napa cabbage they had harvested from their garden in Fairbanks. Reached by phone, Davies said he was happy to hear that his research of decades ago was suddenly relevant. â€œThat would be really gratifying if that turned out to be true,â€ Davies said. West said the shadow of aftershocks from the earthquake were enough for him to believe that a significant portion of the Shumagin Gap had ruptured, and was perhaps not just some quirky section that slips quietly without major earthquakes. Davies, who as state seismologist had a duty to find the areas of greatest earthquake risk and advise about building codes and warn of tsunami hazards, said large earthquakes somewhat remind him of current times. â€œEarthquakes are like viruses â€” the really big ones come along once in a lifetime, if at all,â€ he said. â€œWe have these hazards that occur with such a long time between them. Itâ€™s hard to get people to pay attention.â€ [Because of a high volume of comments requiring moderation, we are temporarily disabling comments on many of our articles so editors can focus on the coronavirus crisis and other coverage. We invite you to write a letter to the editor or reach out directly if youâ€™d like to communicate with us about a particular article. Thanks.] Ned Rozell is a science writer with the Geophysical Institute at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. 1 2 3 4 5 Â© 2023 Anchorage Daily News. All rights reserved.
summ:
But he was quick to point out a scientific paper written by the first Alaska state seismologist, John Davies, in 1981.
(Graphic courtesy Alaska Earthquake Center)  In it, Davies and his co-workers proposed a â€œseismic gapâ€ just south of Sand Point.
â€œFrom 1938 to 1965, almost the entirety of the Alaska subduction zone ruptured,â€ West said.
â€œHere, you have this 1981 paper that says youâ€™ve ruptured everything except these sections, and thatâ€™s where you should expect the next big earthquake.â€ [Alaska quake that prompted tsunami evacuations, but no big wave, may offer clue in scientific debate]  â€œThe Pacific Plate is careening northwestward a couple of inches each year into the stronger North American Plate,â€ he said.
Major earthquakes happen at the boundary where these two plates rub together.â€ John Davies, who wrote the paper predicting an earthquake like the one that happened Tuesday night, was elected to the Alaska State Legislature in 1993.
Davies, who as state seismologist had a duty to find the areas of greatest earthquake risk and advise about building codes and warn of tsunami hazards, said large earthquakes somewhat remind him of current times.

Title: Powerful magnitude 7.8 earthquake strikes off of Alaska
Body: Share  ANCHORAGE, Alaska - A powerful earthquake struck off ofÂ Alaska'sÂ southern coast jolted some coastal communities late Tuesday, and some residents briefly scrambled for higher ground over fears of a tsunami. There were no immediate reports of damage in the sparsely populated area of the state, and a tsunami warning was canceled after the magnitude 7.8 quake off the Alaska Peninsula produced a wave ofÂ less than a foot.  Because of its location, nearby communities along the Alaska Peninsula did not experience shaking that would normally be associated with that magnitude of a quake, said Michael West, Alaska State Seismologist. Get breaking news alerts in the FOX5NY News app. It is FREE! Download for iOS or Android  â€œNo reports of any damage,â€ Kodiak Police Sgt. Mike Sorter told The Associated Press early Wednesday morning. â€œNo injuries were reported. Everything is nominal.â€ Kodiak is about 200 miles northeast of where the earthquake was centered. The tsunami warning had coastal residents evacuating for higher ground. Social media posts showed long lines of people fleeing towns like Homer and Kodiak while tsunami sirens wailed in the background. On Kodiak Island, the local high school opened its doors for evacuees, as did the local Catholic school, the Anchorage Daily News reported. â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District. â€œIâ€™ve been passing out masks since the first siren sounded,â€ he told the Daily News. â€œEverythingâ€™s as calm as can be. Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said before the warning was canceled. Tsunami warnings are commonplace for people who grew up in Kodiak. â€Iâ€™ve been doing these since I was a little kid,â€ LeDoux told the newspaper. â€œOld news.â€ Officials at the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, Alaska, began calling off tsunami advisories and warnings after a wave of only 25 centimeters (.8 foot) was recorded in the community of Sand Point. â€œI might have expected a little bit more water, but Iâ€™m happy that there wasnâ€™t,â€ said David Hale, the senior duty scientist at the tsunami center. Tuesdayâ€™s quake was more powerful than the magnitude 7.1 earthquake that caused damage in the Anchorage area in November 2018. â€œThis earthquake released about 15 times as much energy as that earthquake, said West, the state seismologist. More than a dozen aftershocks of magnitude 4.0 or higher were reported immediately after the earthquake, he said by telephone from the Alaska Earthquake Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. â€We got people here who are going be working all night,â€ West said early Wednesday morning. â€These aftershocks will go and go and go and go.â€ The Alaska-Aleutian Trench was also where a magnitude 9.2 quake in 1964 was centered. That remains the second most powerful earthquake ever recorded. The temblor and ensuing tsunami caused widespread damage and killed 131 people, some as far away as Oregon and California. Alaska is the most actively seismic state. Nearly 25,000 earthquakes have been recorded in Alaska since Jan. 1, according to the center. summ:
There were no immediate reports of damage in the sparsely populated area of the state, and a tsunami warning was canceled after the magnitude 7.8 quake off the Alaska Peninsula produced a wave ofÂ less than a foot.
â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District.
Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said before the warning was canceled.
â€œOld news.â€ Officials at the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, Alaska, began calling off tsunami advisories and warnings after a wave of only 25 centimeters (.8 foot) was recorded in the community of Sand Point.
More than a dozen aftershocks of magnitude 4.0 or higher were reported immediately after the earthquake, he said by telephone from the Alaska Earthquake Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks.
â€These aftershocks will go and go and go and go.â€ The Alaska-Aleutian Trench was also where a magnitude 9.2 quake in 1964 was centered.

Title: Study suggests risk of big San Andreas earthquake has increased
Body: CALIFORNIA, USA â€” The Ridgecrest earthquakes in 2019 may have upped the chances of a quake along the San Andreas fault with magnitude 7.5 or greater in the next 12 months, according to a study published Monday in the Bulletin of the Seismological Society of America.The Los Angeles Times reported on the findings that there is a 2.3% chance of a large earthquake on the Garlock fault, which runs along the north edge of the Mojave Desert, in the next year. That increases the likelihood of a big shake-up on the larger San Andreas fault to 1.15%.Those low probabilities may seem hardly worth worrying about given more pressing concerns of the COVID-19 pandemic, however, the numbers translate into a near tripling of the odds of a large quake on the San Andreas, one of the study's co-authors told The Times.Ross Stein, an earthquake scientist emeritus of the U.S. Geological Survey and adjunct professor of geophysics at Stanford University told the newspaper that if the Garlock fault ruptures, the probability of a big earthquake along the San Andreas fault could be even odds."Now, you can think of the Ridgecrest earthquake as being so far from Greater Los Angeles ... that it is nearly harmless," Stein told The Times."But the problem is that ... the Ridgecrest earthquake brought the Garlock fault closer to rupture. If that fault ruptures -- and it gets within about 25 miles of the San Andreas -- then there's a high likelihood, maybe a 50/50 shot, that it would immediately rupture on the San Andreas."A hypothetical magnitude 7.8 quake on the San Andreas could cause more than 1,800 deaths, injure 5,000, displace 500,000 to 1 million people from their homes and cripple the region economically for a generation, The Times reported.A quake of that magnitude would produce 45 times more energy than the 1994 magnitude 6.7 Northridge quake.Another seismologist, not involved in the study, said its conclusions are not confirmed."It's really interesting science, and I like the way they've been able to increase the complexity of how they do their modeling," Lucy Jones told the newspaper. "That's a real advance. But it's not yet proven."However, even Jones said California officials should be prepared and on the lookout for action on the Garlock fault.The series of earthquakes in Ridgecrest in 2019 culminated in the largest seismic event in the state since the 1999 7.1 magnitude Hector Mine quake, according to an abstract of the report.The Ridgecrest activity "produced significant stress perturbations on nearby fault networks, especially along the Garlock fault segment immediately southwest of the 2019 Ridgecrest rupture," according to that brief summary.The question is whether that stress may have begun a chain of events that could result in a widespread devastation along the San Andreas fault not seen since 1857, The Times noted.A year ago, the U.S. Geological Survey -- the nation's primary earthquake science agency -- calculated that there was an extremely remote chance the San Andreas could be triggered by the Ridgecrest quakes, the newspaper reported.Â     Next up in 5 Example video title will go here for this video     In Other News Notifications can be turned off anytime in the browser settings.
summ: That increases the likelihood of a big shake-up on the larger San Andreas fault to 1.15%.Those low probabilities may seem hardly worth worrying about given more pressing concerns of the COVID-19 pandemic, however, the numbers translate into a near tripling of the odds of a large quake on the San Andreas, one of the study's co-authors told The Times.Ross Stein, an earthquake scientist emeritus of the U.S. Geological Survey and adjunct professor of geophysics at Stanford University told the newspaper that if the Garlock fault ruptures, the probability of a big earthquake along the San Andreas fault could be even odds."Now, you can think of the Ridgecrest earthquake as being so far from Greater Los Angeles ...

Title: Magnitude 3.6 earthquake shakes Anchorage
Body: An earthquake with a reviewed magnitude of 3.6 rumbled through Anchorage on Tuesday afternoon, according to the Alaska Earthquake Center.   According to a shakemap on the U.S. Geological Survey website, the quake was felt throughout the municipality and as far away as the Matanuska-Susitna Borough. The Alaska Earthquake Center said Tuesdayâ€™s quake is an aftershock of the magnitude 7.1 earthquake that occurred on Nov. 30, 2018. Title: Earthquake in California triggers rock slide, sends boulders crashing down on camping area
Body:
This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten,
      or redistributed. Â©2023 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved.
      Quotes displayed in real-time or delayed by at least 15 minutes. Market data provided by Factset. Powered and implemented by FactSet Digital Solutions. Legal Statement. Mutual Fund and ETF data provided by Refinitiv Lipper.
     New system sends earthquake warnings through an app and the wireless system that issues Amber Alerts; insight from Richard Allen, director of the UC Berkeley Seismological Lab. A moderately strong earthquake that rattled central California on Wednesday triggered a rock slide that sent boulders and debris crashing into a camping area.  Lone Pine is located between SequoiaÂ National Park and Death Valley National Park. MAGNITUDE 5.8 EARTHQUAKE RATTLES CENTRAL CALIFORNIA The Inyo County Sheriff's Office said on Facebook a rock slide was triggered by the quake in the Whitney Portal area about 45 miles from the epicenter.  A magnitude 5.8 earthquake on Wednesday in California triggered a rockslide at Whitney Portal in California. (Inyo County Sheriff's Office) The Whitney Portal is the gateway to Mt. Whitney, the highest point in the contiguous U.S. and the trailhead for the Mt. Whitney Trail, according to KPIX-TV. A magnitude 5.8 earthquake on Wednesday in California triggered a rockslide at Whitney Portal in California. (Inyo County Sheriff's Office) Photos released by the sheriff's office show large boulders that crashedÂ into the area. A large boulder rests against a tree after a magnitude 5.8 earthquake triggered a rockslide at Whitney Portal in California. (Inyo County Sheriff's Office) One roadway was closed due to debris and rocks in the road. Debris on a roadway after a magnitude 5.8 earthquake struck central California on Wednesday. (Inyo County Sheriff's Office) Campgrounds were being evacuated and no injuries were reported, the sheriff's office said. Damage after a magnitude 5.8 earthquake on Wednesday in California triggered a rockslide at Whitney Portal in California. (Inyo County Sheriff's Office) Clouds of dust could be seen hanging in the air close to the parking lot and camping ground in a video posted to Twitter by John Chrissinger.  Chrissinger told Storyful he was standing in the picnic area at Whitney Portal when he heard a "low rumble" and then "a few pretty hard shakes to the right and left" that lasted about 10 seconds. â€œThere was a thunderous crash and you could see part of the mountain coming down, lucky that we were on the other side of the portal road, I did not have time to video the landslide it all happened so fast, was over in 30 seconds," he told Storyful. "Funny it was just dead silence and all the dirt rising up after the slide. Felt really eerie." Another photo he took showed a large boulder that "took out several campsites and trees." Other videos also showed dust clouds on area mountains after the quake. THE "RING OF FIRE' EXPLAINED  The shocks were felt by local residents in the California cities of Fresno and Acampo, and in Las Vegas, among other areas near the epicenter. No injuries were reported, though there was some minor damage at the epicenter. CLICK HERE FOR MORE WEATHER COVERAGE FROM FOX NEWS The Lone Pine Market was left with broken bottles of alcohol and glass jars of food that littered the floors after the quake shook the area. Dust on vehicles after a magnitude 5.8 earthquake triggered a rockslide at Whitney Portal in California on Wednesday. (Inyo County Sheriff's Office) Ramon Sanchez told FOX26 that at one point, tiles started falling from the ceiling. The area saw a magnitude 4.8 earthquake on Monday. CLICK HERE FOR THE FOX NEWS APP "We're used to the sonic booms from the naval base located right behind us. And we just thought that's what it was when the initial earthquake started," he told the television station. After the initial quake, there were also dozens of aftershocks reported, ranging fromÂ 4.6 to 2.5. Title: Mexico earthquake death toll rises, worker at oil refinery dies after falling from plant structure
Body:
This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten,
      or redistributed. Â©2023 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved.
      Quotes displayed in real-time or delayed by at least 15 minutes. Market data provided by Factset. Powered and implemented by FactSet Digital Solutions. Legal Statement. Mutual Fund and ETF data provided by Refinitiv Lipper.
     Mexico hit by magnitude 7.4 earthquake that triggered a tsunami alert for Pacific coastlines along Central America. The powerful earthquake that rocked southern Mexico on Tuesday is now blamed for at least six deaths, including a worker at the country's largest oil refinery, according to officials.  â€œWe lost everything in one moment to nature,â€ said Vicente Romero, an owner of a stationery store in the resort town of La Crucecita who told Reuters his home suffered structural damage. â€œThis is our lifeâ€™s work." MAGNITUDE 7.4 EARTHQUAKE STRIKES MEXICO, AT LEAST 2 DEAD IN BUILDING COLLAPSES The national Civil Protection Center said right before midnight a sixth fatality was reported in the southern state of Oaxaca, the epicenter of the quake where at least 500 homes were damaged. A magnitude 7.4 earthquake in southern Mexico was felt several hundred miles away. (Fox News) Among the dead were aÂ worker at Mexico's largest oil refinery who fell from one of the plant's structures, according to the civil protection agency. A policeman stands in front of a partially collapsed building after an earthquake in Oaxaca,, Mexico, June 23. (AP Photo/Luis Alberto Cruz Hernandez) The temblor also caused a fire at the plant that led to a brief shutdown. â€œA small fire broke out and was immediately controlled,â€ a Pemex spokesperson told Reuters. A policeman removes rubble from a building damaged by an earthquake in Oaxaca, Mexico, June 23. (AP Photo/Luis Alberto Cruz Hernandez) Mountain roads were blocked by landslides, while churches, bridges and highways also suffered damage during the quake. In Huatulco, a laid-back beach destination known for surfing and small protected coves, the earthquake knocked goods off shelves and some rubble from buildings. THE "RING OF FIRE' EXPLAINED At least six people were injured, including two in Mexico City, more than 300 miles north of the epicenter, where the shaking sent tens of thousands of people fleeing into the streets.  Officials told El Universal that at least 10 health centers, already busy battling the coronavirus pandemic, sustained damage from the tremors. Eight hospitals scattered along the coast in Oaxaca were the most severely affected. "Unfortunately, the earthquake was significant enough to cause damage to the ceilings, doors, facilitiesÂ and walls, but the reports I have so far are that there are no structural damages," Oaxaca Deputy Director of Health Services Juan Carlos Marquez Heine told the news outlet. People embrace on he street as they wait for the all-clear to return to their apartment after an earthquake in Mexico City, Tuesday, June 23, 2020. (AP Photo/Eduardo Verdugo) Hundreds of aftershocks have been reported and the damage is still being assessed. It was felt in Guatemala and throughout south and central Mexico. CLICK HERE FOR MORE WEATHER COVERAGE FROM FOX NEWS In Vatican City on Wednesday, Pope Francis prayed for victims of the quake. â€œYesterday a violent earthquake hit the south of Mexico causing victims, injuries and enormous damage. Letâ€™s pray for them. May the help of God and our brothers give them strength and support. Brothers and sisters, I am very close to you,â€ he said at his weekly general audience. The USGS estimated that some 2 million people felt strong or moderate shaking and another 49 million felt weak or light shaking. CLICK HERE FOR THE FOX NEWS APP Mexico's Pacific coast is located along the volatile "Ring of Fire,â€ a horseshoe-shaped series of fault lines around the ocean.Â The region has most of Earth's subduction zones, where oceanic plates slide under the lighter continental plates. Earthquakes can occur when those plates scrapeÂ or subsideÂ underneath each other. At sea, it can spawn tsunamis. The earthquake hit a quake-prone region of Mexico where four underground tectonic plates come together. In the past 35 years, there have been at least seven magnitudeÂ 7 or greater earthquakes, killing around 10,000 people â€” most of them in a 1985 magnitude 8.0 quake. The Associated Press contributed to this report. Title: Small earthquake strikes under UC Berkeley campus
Body: This is a carousel. Use Next and Previous buttons to navigate A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning. A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning. A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning. A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning. A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning. A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning, with an epicenter under the edge of UC Berkeley campus. A map from the United States Geological Survey shows the quake hit just east of the California Memorial Stadium.  Residents in the area reported feeling the slightest shaking. There was no initial word on damage or injury resulting from the quake. More information on this earthquake is available on the USGS event page. A handful of major faults cut through the Bay Area, and many experts believe the 52-mile-long Hayward Fault stretching from San Pablo Bay in the north, to just east of San Jose in the south, is among the most dangerous in the world as it passes directly through a highly populated area. Due to the Hayward Fault's vulnerability, the USGS imagined the outcome of a magnitude 7.0 tremor on the fault in a 2018 report.Â The "Haywired scenario" estimates up to 800 people could die and 18,000 could be injured if the fault were to rupture. Â Homes would be engulfed in flames, with an estimated 52,000 homes burning. Twenty-thousand people could be stuck in elevators and 1,500 could be trapped in fallen buildings. Also on Tuesday morning, a 4.2 quake struck in western Nevada about 23 miles from Mina. The region has seen a flurry of earthquakes ever since a magnitude-6.5 earthquake rocked a remote region 35 miles west of Tonopah on May 15. Hundreds of aftershocks have followed. See the latest USGS quake alerts, report feeling earthquake activity and tour interactive fault maps in SFGATE's earthquake section.
summ:
A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning.
A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning.
A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning.
A small magnitude-2.7 earthquake struck Berkeley, Calif., Tuesday morning.

Title: Nevada 'dodged a bullet' when 6.5 earthquake struck in a remote area, seismologist says
Body: RENO, Nev.Â â€”Â Nevada's largest earthquake in 66 years left little more than cracked asphalt and shaken residents in its wake, but according to the top scientist at the state's seismological lab, Friday's 6.5 temblor was a near miss.Â  "We dodged a bullet in many ways in terms of where it was," said Graham Kent, the director of the Nevada Seismological Lab at the University of Nevada, Reno.Â  The quake, centered in a remote area 36 miles west of Tonopah, was felt across three states. It ruptured nearby U.S. 95 â€” a major artery between Las Vegas and Reno â€” and swung chandeliers in the quiet historic towns it was closest to.Â  But no injuries have been reported and structures â€” even notoriously unstable historic buildings â€” made it through seemingly unscathed.Â  Take that same earthquake and recenter it underneath Reno, a situation that's more when than if,Â and it could have yielded "millions of dollars of damage and loss of life," Kent said.Â  That natural disaster would have only been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, which would vastly complicate the normal practice of placing displaced people in mass evacuation centers. Now, an evacuation center would place scores of people at risk for exposure to the virus, adding another layer onto an already complicated situation.Â   Though the largest quake of this sequence hit just after 4 a.m. Friday morning, Kent stressed Nevada is not yet out of the woods.Â  Aftershocks â€” some of them fairly strong â€” have been happening by the hundreds in the hours after the 6.5, Kent said.Â  The six strongest of them happened in the hour immediately after the quake, all of them above magnitude 4.5.Â  There's also a chance that what's currently being referred to as the mainshock â€” the 6.5 earthquake â€” was actually a foreshock, and the largest earthquake is yet to come.Â  The United States Geological Survey pegs the chance that a larger earthquake will happen in the next week in that region at about 4%.Â  But Kent said the odds are likely a bit higher than that. When the USGS calculates that percentage, it's using statistics from a much larger area than just western Nevada and eastern California, heÂ explained.Â  Historically, large earthquakes hitting in pairs or as a series is fairly characteristic of the seismic zone that ruptured on Friday, which is known as the Walker Lane.Â  The Walker Lane is a 60-mile wide band of active faults that stretches from the Mojave Desert in southern California, through western Nevada (and the Reno area) and back into northern California.Â  Kent rattled off a list of famous Walker Lane earthquakes over the past 30 to 40 years which happened in pairs.Â  The 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake sequence, which happened on the southern end of the Walker Lane and was responsible for Nevada's first earthquake-related death, was highlighted by a 6.4Â foreshock on July 4 followed by a magnitude 7.1 mainshock on July 5.Â  Even the strongest earthquake ever recorded in Nevada, the 1954 Fairview earthquake east of Reno, was a series of five strong earthquakes. The strongest two â€” a 6.8 foreshock and the 7.1 mainshock â€” happened just four minutes apart.Â  Kent said his lab is deploying additional remote sensors in the area of Friday'sÂ earthquake sequence to get a better handle on what the ground is doing.Â  "So whether (the odds of another large quake) are 4% or 20% or 35 percent, there is that potential we saw in Ridgecrest," Kent said. "So it's important for us to maybe catch that with more equipment on the ground."Â  While seismic activity continues near Tonopah and the risk for a larger earthquake remains, that doesn't mean Friday's earthquake sequence will trigger some sort of chain reaction that sets off a quake near one of Nevada's population centers.Â  That activity is just too far away from Las Vegas and Reno to cause a chain reaction like that, Kent said.Â  "But that doesn't mean mother nature doesn't have a sense of humor and just randomly puts one nearby," he said, adding that residents of Nevada should be prepared by visitingÂ shakeout.org/Nevada and learn the drop, cover and hold drill.Â  Sam Gross is a breaking news reporter for the Reno Gazette Journal who covers wildfires, emergencies and more. Support his work by subscribing to RGJ.com.Â    Powerful earthquakes reveal mysterious 15-million-year-old fossil in California
summ:
â€”Â Nevada's largest earthquake in 66 years left little more than cracked asphalt and shaken residents in its wake, but according to the top scientist at the state's seismological lab, Friday's 6.5 temblor was a near miss.
"We dodged a bullet in many ways in terms of where it was," said Graham Kent, the director of the Nevada Seismological Lab at the University of Nevada, Reno.
Take that same earthquake and recenter it underneath Reno, a situation that's more when than if,Â and it could have yielded "millions of dollars of damage and loss of life," Kent said.
The 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake sequence, which happened on the southern end of the Walker Lane and was responsible for Nevada's first earthquake-related death, was highlighted by a 6.4Â foreshock on July 4 followed by a magnitude 7.1 mainshock on July 5.
Kent said his lab is deploying additional remote sensors in the area of Friday'sÂ earthquake sequence to get a better handle on what the ground is doing.
"So it's important for us to maybe catch that with more equipment on the ground."Â  While seismic activity continues near Tonopah and the risk for a larger earthquake remains, that doesn't mean Friday's earthquake sequence will trigger some sort of chain reaction that sets off a quake near one of Nevada's population centers.

Title: Large earthquake in Nevada desert felt in Sacramento, throughout California
Body: SACRAMENTO, Calif. â€” A large earthquake struck in a remote area of western Nevada early Friday. The quake â€” initially reported by the U.S. Geological Service at a magnitude of 6.4 â€” could be felt in Sacramento, more than 300 miles away. The quake was reported just after 4 a.m. PDT near Tonopah, Nev., about 100 miles east of Yosemite National Park and roughly halfway between Reno and Las Vegas. Twitter was full of people reporting they felt the earthquake in Sacramento, Fresno and the San Francisco Bay Area. It was followed by a series of small aftershocks, the USGS reported. Fridayâ€™s earthquake was close in magnitude to a 6.5 earthquake that hit the Boise, Idaho, area on March 31. Some of the most recent earthquakes and aftershocks felt in Northern California came in March and shook the coast, with magnitude 4.8 and 5.8 quakes striking about 50 miles west of Petrolia in Humboldt County. According to a previous story in The Sacramento Bee, while the likelihood of a significant earthquake in Sacramento is considerably lower than in the Bay Area, that doesnâ€™t mean it canâ€™t occur, said Richard Armstrong, a Sacramento State professor who studies earthquake engineering. â€œItâ€™s just less likely,â€ he said. Still, even if Sacramento doesnâ€™t face the same earthquake threat as other cities such as San Francisco or Los Angeles, â€œit has felt the effects of earthquakes in the past and likely will in the future,â€ according to California Geological Survey spokesman Don Drysdale. For example, if a major earthquake were to hit near the city, the shaking could loosen sandy soil deposits, allowing water to penetrate and saturate the earth. The liquified soil could then lose its strength, cracking and moving underneath structures like levees and buildings, Drysdale said. Sacramento County could experience strong shaking during a large earthquake, but the resulting damage would be less than areas near major active faults such as the Bay Area. Buildings specifically designed to withstand earthquakes and other â€œwell-builtâ€ structures would likely survive a major earthquake, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Shoddier buildings may have considerable damage or collapse entirely. In 2008, the U.S. Geological Survey created animations of different earthquake scenarios along the Hayward Fault, a major active fault that runs under East Bay, including Berkeley, Oakland and San Jose. Simulations of a strong magnitude-6.8 earthquake or more show Sacramento would likely experience significant shaking â€” the kind that would awaken most, and cause some dishes and windows to move or break, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. But smaller earthquakes are far more common, and those are usually experienced without an issue in Sacramento. Ryan Lillis and Alexandra Yoon-Hendricks of The Sacramento Bee wrote this story. summ:
Twitter was full of people reporting they felt the earthquake in Sacramento, Fresno and the San Francisco Bay Area.
According to a previous story in The Sacramento Bee, while the likelihood of a significant earthquake in Sacramento is considerably lower than in the Bay Area, that doesnâ€™t mean it canâ€™t occur, said Richard Armstrong, a Sacramento State professor who studies earthquake engineering.
Still, even if Sacramento doesnâ€™t face the same earthquake threat as other cities such as San Francisco or Los Angeles, â€œit has felt the effects of earthquakes in the past and likely will in the future,â€ according to California Geological Survey spokesman Don Drysdale.
Sacramento County could experience strong shaking during a large earthquake, but the resulting damage would be less than areas near major active faults such as the Bay Area.
Simulations of a strong magnitude-6.8 earthquake or more show Sacramento would likely experience significant shaking â€” the kind that would awaken most, and cause some dishes and windows to move or break, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

Title: USGS reports magnitude-6.4 earthquake in western Nevada
Body:
FOX40 Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term.       TONOPAH, Nev. (AP) â€” Authorities in western Nevada checked for possible highway damage following a magnitude 6.5 earthquake in a remote area early Friday.  The initial quake struck about 4.7 miles (7.6 kilometers) deep, the USGS said, and dozens of aftershocks were recorded in the next three hours, including two with estimated magnitudes of 4.9. There were no immediate reports of injury, but part of U.S. 95 was closed as state troopers and sheriffâ€™s deputies from Esmeralda and Mineral counties checked that highway and State Route 360 for possible damage, the Mineral County sheriffâ€™s office said. The Nye County sheriffâ€™s office was also checking a report of possible damage to U.S. 95, Capt. David Boruchowitz told KSNV-TV in Las Vegas. â€œOther than that, just a bunch of people shaken up.â€ The quake occurred in a remote area of the state between Reno and Las Vegas. Social media users in California reported feeling the earthquake in Bakersfield, Fresno, the Bay Area and Sacramento. â€œIt really shook a lot of groceries off the shelves,â€ Keith Hasty, an employee at a gas station in Tonopah, told theÂ Las Vegas Review-Journal. Hasty said residents who frequented the store were all talking about the quake. â€œWe have a lot of locals coming in saying their TVs were shaking, they felt it,â€ said Hasty. â€œNo damage that Iâ€™ve heard of. My boss just called and said his garage shook.â€ The USGS site showed over 13,200 responses from users saying they felt the quake. Latest from the USGS. Title: Today marks 114 years since the 1906 San Francisco earthquake
Body: KRON4 Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term.     SAN FRANCISCO, Calif. (KRON) â€” Saturday marks 114 years since the 1906 San Francisco earthquake struck the Bay Area and beyond. The 7.9-magnitude earthquake killed more than 3,000 people and destroyed 28,000 buildings.  The earthquake was felt just after 5 a.m. throughout the Bay Area. The earthquake broke loose less than 30 seconds later, with an epicenter near San Francisco. Strong shocks lasted from 45 to 60 seconds. The great earthquake was felt from southern Oregon to south of Los Angeles and even as far as central Nevada.  The earthquake marks as one of the most significant earthquakes of all time.   Copyright 2023 Nexstar Media Inc. All rights reserved. Title: Magnitude 3.5 earthquake centered near Anza felt across Coachella Valley
Body: A series of earthquakes of up toÂ 3.5 magnitudeÂ shook the Coachella Valley on Sunday afternoon.  There were no immediate reports of damage. Sunday's quakes were preceded by a series of quakes that have been occurring since a magnitude 4.9 earthquake shook the area Friday evening.Â It was felt across Southern California, but there were no reports of damage in the Coachella Valley. Seismologist Dr. Lucy Jones said aftershocks were expected after Friday's initial quake, but added that those in Anza were "on the high side of average." Three of the smaller earthquakesÂ happened Sunday morning and each was between magnitude 2.5 and 2.8, according to USGS.   Desert Sun reporter Colin Atagi covers crime, public safety and roadÂ andÂ highway safety. He can be reached at Colin.Atagi@desertsun.com or follow him at @tdscolinatagi. Support local news, subscribe to The Desert Sun.
summ: Desert Sun reporter Colin Atagi covers crime, public safety and roadÂ andÂ highway safety.

Title: People react to a historic earthquake in Idaho
Body: Menu  Even though we felt it in the Treasure Valley because the epicenter was in a remote area the earthquake didn't do very much damage, still it caused quite the reaction surprising us all. "I thought it was just the wind outside the house so I got up and raised the blind and it was sunny outside," said Boise resident Chris Wadner. "I didnâ€™t have any pictures fall off the wall or mirrors or anything like that, I donâ€™t think there was any damage.â€ There was some damage as a cross a top St. John's Cathedral in Boise was cracked, but there were no reported injuries because of the earthquake. Idaho Power found no damage to the 17 dams they manage, the Idaho Transportation Department has been clearing debris off the highways and ITD also closed down avalanche alley blocking the route from Stanley to Lowman, however, they did that before the earthquake happened. We also made a trip to Idaho City and residents there told from a distance (COVID-19 Social Distancing) there was only minor damage, but the quake shook their house pretty intensely.  So far there have been dozens of aftershocks and seismologist Jim Zollweg told us we can expect more in the coming days. â€œProbably the biggest aftershock will be somewhere in the range of five to five and a half  that kind of magnitude of Earthquake would only be lightly felt in the Boise area," said Zollweg. "If the earthquake would have been in a populated area there would have been significant property damage." So for now it looks like we were are able to come through the latest curveball 2020 has thrown at us as Idaho recorded the fifth largest earthquake in the world this year. "Some years are like this, some years are calm you, just never know," said Wadner. Experts tell us the quake has no connection to super volcano in the Yellowstone National Park area, but people felt the earthquake in the states surrounding Idaho including in Bozeman, Montana where I grew up. People there say they felt it and Bozeman is located 90 miles north of Yellowstone.
summ:
â€œProbably the biggest aftershock will be somewhere in the range of five to five and a half  that kind of magnitude of Earthquake would only be lightly felt in the Boise area," said Zollweg.
"If the earthquake would have been in a populated area there would have been significant property damage." So for now it looks like we were are able to come through the latest curveball 2020 has thrown at us as Idaho recorded the fifth largest earthquake in the world this year.

Title: U.S. Geological Survey reports magnitude 6.5 earthquake has struck Idaho
Body: Share BOISE, Idaho - An earthquake struck north of Boise Tuesday evening, with people across a large area reporting shaking. The U.S. Geological Survey reports the magnitude 6.5 temblor struck just before 6 p.m. It was centered 73 miles (118 kilometers) northeast of Meridian, near the rural mountain town of Stanley. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. More than 2 million live in the region that could feel the Idaho quake, according to the USGS, with reports of shaking coming in from as far away as Helena, Montana, and Salt Lake City, Utah. Marcus Smith, an emergency room health unit coordinator at St. Lukeâ€™s Wood River Medical Center, said the hospital, about 65 miles (104 kilometers) south of the epicenter, shook but the quake didnâ€™t interfere with the treatment of any patients. The hospital in Blaine County is on the front line of Idahoâ€™s coronavirus outbreak, in a region with the nationâ€™s highest per-capita rates of known COVID-19 cases outside of New York City and its surrounding counties. â€œIt felt like a wave going through the ground, so I knew right away what it was. It just felt like waves going through the ground,â€ he said. The earthquake added stress during an already tense time for the region, but Smith said everything seemed fine, for now. â€œUntil the next one, I guess,â€ Smith said. â€œI mean, thatâ€™s what we do. Weâ€™re all good.â€ Brett Woolley, the owner of Bridge Street Grill in Stanley, said he heard the earthquake coming before he felt it. â€œI heard the roar, and at first it sounded like the wind but then the roar was tremendous,â€ Woolley said about 10 minutes after the earthquake. â€œThe whole house was rattling, and I started to panic. Iâ€™m sitting here perfectly still and the water next to me is still vibrating.â€ Dr. Lucy Jones, a seismologist at Caltech and the founder of the Dr. Lucy Jones Center for Science and Seismology, said the Idaho region has an earthquake of about this size every 30 or 40 years. The most recent one, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake near Borah Peak in 1983, killed two children in Challis and caused an estimated $12.5 million in property damage across Challis and Mackay. That quake was along what scientists call a â€œnormal fault,â€ with the quake causing vertical movement, she said. Tuesdayâ€™s quake appeared to be on an unmapped â€œstrike-slip fault,â€ causing mostly horizontal movement along the fault line. â€œThis is one that wasnâ€™t obvious enough to be mapped before now,â€ Jones said. Unmapped faults of this size are rarer in highly populated areas like California, she said, but in sparsely populated and remote regions like central Idaho theyâ€™re less likely to cause damage and less likely to be a focus of geologists and seismologists. Residents in the region will likely continue to feel aftershocks, she said. The area had already recorded five aftershocks within the first hours after the 6.5 earthquake. â€œAn aftershock is just an earthquake, but it happens at a time that doesnâ€™t surprise us,â€ she said. â€œThey do every bit as much damage.â€ People in an earthquake should drop to the floor and cover their heads with their arms, she said. â€œGet to the floor before the earthquake throws you there, and if you have a table nearby, get under it and hold onto it,â€ Jones said. â€œRunning in an earthquake is incredibly dangerous â€” people die from running in an earthquake. Just get down and try to cover.â€ All the news you need to know, every day By clicking Sign Up, I confirmthat I have read and agreeto the Privacy Policy and Terms of Service.  This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Â©2023 FOX Television Stations
summ:
Weâ€™re all good.â€ Brett Woolley, the owner of Bridge Street Grill in Stanley, said he heard the earthquake coming before he felt it.
â€œI heard the roar, and at first it sounded like the wind but then the roar was tremendous,â€ Woolley said about 10 minutes after the earthquake.
Iâ€™m sitting here perfectly still and the water next to me is still vibrating.â€ Dr. Lucy Jones, a seismologist at Caltech and the founder of the Dr. Lucy Jones Center for Science and Seismology, said the Idaho region has an earthquake of about this size every 30 or 40 years.
â€œAn aftershock is just an earthquake, but it happens at a time that doesnâ€™t surprise us,â€ she said.
â€œThey do every bit as much damage.â€ People in an earthquake should drop to the floor and cover their heads with their arms, she said.

The earthquake struck north of Boise, Idaho, Tuesday evening, with people across a large area reporting shaking. (Tyler Beyer via AP) BOISE, Idaho â€“ An earthquake struck north of Boise Tuesday evening, with people across a large area reporting shaking.  The U.S. Geological Survey reports the magnitude 6.5 temblor struck just before 6 p.m. It was centered 73 miles (118 kilometers) northeast of Meridian, near the rural mountain town of Stanley. The hospital in Blaine County is on the front line of Idaho's coronavirus outbreak, in a region with the nation's highest per-capita rates of known COVID-19 cases outside of New York City and its surrounding counties. â€œIt felt like a wave going through the ground, so I knew right away what it was. It just felt like waves going through the ground,â€ he said.  The earthquake added stress during an already tense time for the region, but Smith said everything seemed fine, for now. â€œUntil the next one, I guess,â€ Smith said. â€œI mean, thatâ€™s what we do. Weâ€™re all good.â€ Brett Woolley, the owner of Bridge Street Grill in Stanley, said he heard the earthquake coming before he felt it.  â€œI heard the roar, and at first it sounded like the wind but then the roar was tremendous,â€ Woolley said about 10 minutes after the earthquake. â€œThe whole house was rattling, and I started to panic. I'm sitting here perfectly still and the water next to me is still vibrating.â€ Dr. Lucy Jones, a seismologist at Caltech and the founder of the Dr. Lucy Jones Center for Science and Seismology, said the Idaho region has an earthquake of about this size every 30 or 40 years. The most recent one, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake near Borah Peak in 1983, killed two children in Challis and caused an estimated $12.5 million in property damage across Challis and Mackay.  That quake was along what scientists call a â€œnormal fault,â€ with the quake causing vertical movement, she said. Tuesday's quake appeared to be on an unmapped â€œstrike-slip fault," causing mostly horizontal movement along the fault line.  â€œThis is one that wasn't obvious enough to be mapped before now,â€ Jones said.  Unmapped faults of this size are rarer in highly populated areas like California, she said, but in sparsely populated and remote regions like central Idaho they're less likely to cause damage and less likely to be a focus of geologists and seismologists.  Residents in the region will likely continue to feel aftershocks, she said. The area had already recorded five aftershocks within the first hours after the 6.5 earthquake.  â€œAn aftershock is just an earthquake, but it happens at a time that doesn't surprise us,â€ she said. â€œThey do every bit as much damage.â€ People in an earthquake should drop to the floor and cover their heads with their arms, she said.  â€œGet to the floor before the earthquake throws you there, and if you have a table nearby, get under it and hold onto it," Jones said. â€œRunning in an earthquake is incredibly dangerous â€” people die from running in an earthquake. Just get down and try to cover.â€ ___ This story has been corrected to show the temblor struck just before 6 p.m.  ___ Associated Press writer Lisa Baumann in Seattle contributed to this report.
